title: Equity in AI Systems
description:
In this course we discuss and analyze issues of fairness, justice, and equity that arise in the design and deployment of algorithmic AI/ML systems. We do this by first grappling with the normative questions of what constitutes bias, fairness, discrimination, or equity when it comes to data science and machine learning. We incorporate technical precision by introducing quantitative measures that can allow us to study how algorithms codify, exacerbate, and/or introduce biases of their own, and consider analytic methods of correcting for or eliminating these biases, and algorithmic tools for executing these goals. Further, we consider the algorithmic systems in context, as a small part of the large sociotechnical system in which they arise. This course is a combination of lectures and seminar-style presentations and discussion by students. Readings focus on state-of-the-art academic papers by data scientists, computer scientists, and social scientists. We often ground our discussions around recent case studies, controversies, and current events. Course work consists of presenting an academic paper, writing a blog post, and conducting a final project.

Prerequisite: S&DS 661, or equivalent with permission of the instructor.
